problem:
The polynomial
$$g(x) = x^3-14x^2+18x+72$$has one integer root. What is it?
solution:
By the Integer Root Theorem, any integer root must be a divisor of the constant term -- thus, in this case, a (positive or negative) divisor of $72$. However, this leaves quite a lot of candidates:
$$\pm 1,\ \pm 2,\ \pm 3,\ \pm 4,\ \pm 6,\ \pm 8,\ \pm 9,\ \pm 12,\ \pm 18,\ \pm 24,\ \pm 36,\ \pm 72.$$To narrow our choices, we define another polynomial.  Note that $g(1) = 77.$  Then by the Factor Theorem, $g(x) - 77$ is divisible by $x - 1.$  In other words,
$$g(x) = (x-1)q(x) + 77$$for some polynomial $q(x)$. Thus if we define $h(x) = g(x+1)$, then we have
$$h(x) = xq(x+1) + 77,$$so $h(x)$ has a constant term of $77$. Thus any integer root of $h(x)$ is a divisor of $77$; the possibilities are
$$-77,\ -11,\ -7,\ -1,\ 1,\ 7,\ 11,\ 77.$$This is useful because, if $x$ is a root of $g(x)$, then $h(x-1)=g(x)=0$, so $x-1$ must appear in the list of roots of $h(x)$. In particular, $x$ must be $1$ more than a root of $h(x)$, which gives the possibilities
$$-76,\ -10,\ -6,\ 0,\ 2,\ 8,\ 12,\ 78.$$Of these, only $-6$, $2$, $8$, and $12$ were candidates in our original list. Testing them one by one, we find that $x=\boxed{12}$ is the only integer root of $g(x)$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Use the Integer Root Theorem to identify possible integer roots of the polynomial.
The Integer Root Theorem states that the possible rational roots of the polynomial are all the positive and negative factors of the constant term divided by all the positive and negative factors of the leading coefficient. In this case, the constant term is 72 and the leading coefficient is 1.
The factors of 72 are ±1, ±2, ±3, ±4, ±6, ±8, ±9, ±12, ±18, ±24, ±36, ±72.
Since the leading coefficient is 1, the only possible integer roots are the factors of 72, which are ±1, ±2, ±3, ±4, ±6, ±8, ±9, ±12, ±18, ±24, ±36, ±72.
Step 2: Use the Integer Root Theorem to identify the rational roots of the polynomial.
List the factors of 72: ±1, ±2, ±3, ±4, ±6, ±8, ±9, ±12, ±18, ±24, ±36, ±72.
Step 3: Plug in each possible root, starting with the smaller absolute values, to see which one makes the polynomial equal to zero.
Evaluate g(1): $1^3 -14\left(1\right)^2+18\left(1\right)+72 = 1-14+18+72=77 \neq 0$
Evaluate g(-1): $(-1)^3-14\left(-1\right)^2+18\left(-1\right)+72 = -1-14-18+72=39 \neq 0$
Evaluate $g\left(2\right)$: $2^3 - 14(2)^2 + 18(2) + 72 = 8 - 56 + 36 + 72=60 \neq 0$
Evaluate $g\left(-2\right)$: $(-2)^3-14(-2)^2+18(-2)+72 = -8 -28 -36 + 72=0$
Since $g(-2) = 0$, the polynomial has an integer root of -2.
Step 4: The root -2 corresponds to a factor of the polynomial, so we can perform polynomial division to factorize g(x) and find the other two roots.
Perform polynomial division of g(x) by (x + 2) to find the quadratic factor.
Perform polynomial division of g(x) by (x + 2) to find the quadratic factor: 
$$\begin{array}{rl} & \underline{\phantom{------} \phantom{-}x^2-16x+36} \\ x+2\enclose{longdiv}{x^3-14x^2+18x+72}\kern-.2ex \\ \underline{-\phantom{--} (x^3+2x^2) }\phantom{------------} \\ -18x^2+18x\phantom{-----} \\ \underline{-\phantom{--} (-18x^2-36x)} \phantom{------------} \\ 54x+72 \phantom{----} \\ \underline{-\phantom{--} (54x+108)}\phantom{------------} \\ -36 \end{array}$$The quotient is x^2 - 16x + 36.
Step 5: Factorize the quotient x^2 - 16x + 36 to find the other two roots.
$$x^2 - 16x + 36 = (x - 6)(x - 6)$$
Step 6:
$$g(x)=(x+2)(x-6)(x-6)$$
$$g(x)=(x+2)(x-6)^2$$
Step 4: The root -2 corresponds to a factor of the polynomial, so we can perform polynomial division to factorize g(x) and find the other two roots.
Perform polynomial division of g(x) by (x + 2) to find the quadratic factor.
Perform polynomial division of g(x) by (x + 2) to find the quadratic factor:
